report_title: Audio and Visual Equipment Rental in the US
executive_summary: Audio and visual equipment have many applications spanning many downstream markets. The rental market depends on the economy's health and borrowing rates. The pandemic caused many major markets like entertainment and commercial businesses to shut down, leading to a detraction in revenue. Even so, the uptick in residential construction and the reopening some industrial markets offered a glimmer of hope. Equipment rental and leasing contractors promptly recovered as the economy reopened and business activity resumed. Overall revenue is expected to climb at a CAGR of 2.5% to $10.6 billion through the end of 2024, including a 1.0% uptick in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: ECONOMIC CONDITIONS LEAD TO REVENUE FLUCTUATIONS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic forced many major markets to scale back on spending as their operations shut down, reducing the need for audio and visual equipment. Even so, residential construction and hospitals remained open, offering a slight cushion for renters. Low-interest rates spurred rapid housing construction. Construction sites use audio-visual equipment to ensure everything runs smoothly. Hospitals remained open as many patients were rushed in from catching the virus or getting vaccinated.

A massive market for rental companies is entertainment and commercial businesses. Both markets suffered significantly amid the pandemic and were forced to shut down to prevent the spread of the virus. As the economy recovered, restaurants, bars and live entertainment venues opened up, causing the need for audio and visual equipment to swell up. Many stadiums rented equipment for live sports and concerts to enhance ticketholders' viewing and listening experience. Smaller theaters reopened and many of these venues prefer to rent equipment as the cost of buying continues to spike.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Improving Markets Become a Catalyst for Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the economy recovered, other markets slowly opened, inducing growth. Even so, inflationary concerns caused interest rates to spike as the cost of borrowing swelled. This caused many residential construction builders to cut or hold off on projects, weakening the need for audio-visual equipment on building sites. As inflationary concerns cool down and interest rates creep downward, downstream markets will allocate more funds to audio and visual equipment. Many establishments will have obsolete equipment and seek new technologically advanced equipment to take its place.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising consumer spending will prompt many consumers to rent equipment for short-term living
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rising consumer spending will prompt many consumers to rent equipment for short-term living. As more people constantly switch jobs and locations, renting is more cost-effective since they save money and do not have to worry about carrying heavy equipment when moving out.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE SECONDARY MARKET POSES A PROBLEM
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The price for audio and visual equipment continues to climb as technology improves. While rental companies can offset rising prices with price hikes passed down to the consumer, many markets are looking at the secondary market for audio-visual equipment. Large businesses and facilities may still choose to rent, but most consumers and local stores will opt for equipment on the secondhand market. Many of these businesses can get by with older models and prefer to buy used to save money, all while having permanent access to the equipment.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry rent or lease electronic audio and video equipment for home entertainment systems, vehicles and public areas. The industry excludes rentals of photographic equipment and telephone answering machines.

negative_impact_factors: Industry Assistance Level is low - increasing
Barriers To Entry Level is low - steady

threats: Private investment in industrial equipment and machinery

key_trends: Low barriers to entry allow for new entrants to enter the mix without much effort. Nonetheless, new companies must have significant capital to purchase the equipment they want to rent.
Buying power remains high as customers have a lot of options when it comes to obtaining equipment. They can choose to buy or rent, depending on their financial situation and preference.
The overall landscape of the industry is highly fragmented. There are various markets that companies can enter, all of which use different types of equipment, promoting healthy competition.
The secondary used goods market is a major threat for rental companies. Many customers prefer to own their goods and will spend extra time digging around to find a good deal for equipment.
Even so, many businesses prefer renting, allowing them to get exchanges or assistance if something goes wrong.

The pandemic crippled the rental industry as many of its major markets were shut down temporarily. Even so, residential construction, healthcare buildings and essential industrial factories remained open, preventing a greater downturn.

Swelling inflation caused interest rates to hike after the pandemic, bolstering the cost of borrowing. Many downstream markets and small businesses scaled down on renting newer equipment and opted for older models or purchase used goods, constraining growth.

While there is no public assistance for audio and visual equipment rental, contractors can join trade associations to gain knowledge and networking opportunities. The American Rental Association (ARA) provides information, advocacy and networking for its members.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The industrial and manufacturing sector relies on audio-visual equipment to monitor ongoing activity in factories and warehouses.
Audio visual setups are integral to many construction projects.

products_and_services.product_description: Speakers are essential to any audio visual setup as they broadcast sound into the air.
TVs and home theater accessories display a variety of information depending on their environment.
Many cars and automobiles have audio equipment inside to play music while on the road.
The need for commercial sound equipment spiked as the pandemic waned and commercial businesses reopened.

tier_1_suppliers: Audio & Video Equipment Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Computer & Packaged Software Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Arts, Entertainment and Recreation in the US
tier_2_buyers: Heavy Engineering Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Private investment in industrial equipment and machinery influences the need for rented equipment.

basis_points.basis_title: Low barriers to entry allow new entrants
basis_points.basis_description: Low barriers to entry allow for new entrants to enter the mix without much effort.
Nonetheless, new companies must have significant capital to purchase the equipment they want to rent.
Buying power remains high as customers have a lot of options when it comes to obtaining equipment.
The overall landscape of the industry is highly fragmented.
The secondary used goods market is a major threat for rental companies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Renting occurs frequently since many clients need equipment on short notice. While equipment prices have continued to swell, companies can markup rental prices to adjust for this and prevent fall-offs in profit. Some companies offer discounts for longer-term rental contracts or bulk orders. Many rental companies can also make customers liable for damages, reducing risk on sensitive equipment.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: DEPRECIATION CONTINUES TO PLAGUE RENTAL COMPANIES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation is a sizable expense. Most rented equipment is considered a fixed asset for the company since it maintains ownership over the equipment even during its rental. Since the cost of fixed assets falls under depreciation, the cost of most rental equipment feeds into this cost category.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: CUSTOMER SERVICE CONTINUES TO BE A PRIORITY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Various employees are needed to cover many tasks (moving equipment, offering advice, completing the rental process). Companies must ensure employees treat customers respectfully and provide impeccable customer service. Otherwise, it can detract potential clients. They must also make sure employees are careful with handling equipment.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The pandemic caused revenue to drop massively as many major markets shut down, reducing the need for audio-visual equipment. As the economy recovered, rental services opened back up offering their products to those who needed it. The rising prices of audio and visual equipment have bolstered revenue, as many businesses can save money by renting temporarily. While price hikes have encouraged renting, they have also pushed many consumers to buy used equipment, inducing volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Rental services often communicate online via chat or email to help customers get quotes and estimates on equipment without leaving their houses. Large services can do online ordering and have equipment ready for pickup or delivery, making it easier to reach clients.

Using software solutions can make an operation run smoother. From placing orders online from suppliers to keeping track of rental equipment on a database and monitoring repairs, these tools can help rental companies stay on top of things.

FAQs.question: What is the document about?
FAQs.answer: The document contains industry data in the form of a table with columns for year, revenue, enterprises, establishments, employment, wages, IVA, imports, and exports.

FAQs.question: What time period does the data cover?
FAQs.answer: The data covers the years from 2005 to 2023.

FAQs.question: What are the column headers in the data table?
FAQs.answer: The column headers are: YEAR, REVENUE ($ MILLION), ENTERPRISES (UNITS), ESTABLISHMENTS (UNITS), EMPLOYMENT (UNITS), WAGES ($ MILLION), IVA ($ MILLION), IMPORTS ($ MILLION), EXPORTS ($ MILLION).

FAQs.question: Are there any missing values in the data?
FAQs.answer: Yes, the columns for IMPORTS ($ MILLION) and EXPORTS ($ MILLION) have no data values filled in.
